text: [Music]
the Afghan train rolls past fast this is
the hundred forty mile an hour view of
Helmand province from a Blackhawk
helicopter beneath is Marja an area of
some of the most intensive fighting in
2010 up ahead is a firefight and a
Marine who has been shot the Blackhawk
flies low and banks and turns at
irregular intervals maneuvers to
minimize risks from ground fire it's not
difficult to see why Marge's irrigated
step is dangerous it's a maze of canals
tree lines and small buildings with many
places to hide and many paths for local
fighters to use to flank foreign patrols
and then escape the patchwork also
restricts and channels vehicles in the
firepower and armor they can provide
movement is not easy and small ambushes
are a constant threat the squad ahead
has been hit in one of these traps
they're just below the banking
helicopter are the Marines the green
smoke grenade marks where they want the
helicopter to land the squad is still
under fire
four men tend to a corporal who has been
shot you can see them clustered over the
man preparing to lift him and run with
him to the Blackhawk after it touches
down two of the Marines are on their
chest in the ditch providing covering
fire the pilots have seen the landing
zone they Bank hard left preparing to
descent
but the squad is not alone in these
fields on its flank less than 150 yards
away two afghan men are hurrying along
the tree line are they part of the fight
or bystanders Afghan gunmen and their
many local supporters have become adept
at shaping their tactics around the
rules guiding American patrols hiding
weapons using menaced signalers or
spotters presenting themselves as
non-combatants these are normal
behaviors the more so during a fight as
American reinforcements arrive under
Western rules of engagement proximity is
not guilt unless a weapon is visible
Western forces are ordered not to shoot
and little is clear at this speed in the
time that it took to describe what we
have just described this Blackhawk was
already past the helicopter descends and
lands not long after a touchdown it true
gunfire from three sides including from
where those two men had been
get along the field the Marine was
carried of the helicopter as a second
aircraft circled above providing both
the distraction and the threat of fire
to shield the patrol from an advanced by
the Afghan gunman and hiding who kept
firing throughout this marine survived
and the firefight that wounded him and
provided lessons in the difficulties for
foreigners waging ground war in rural
Afghanistan
